#Text=Claret  was
#Text= considered  a somewhat  expensive  luxury,  and  when  introduced  was  generally  brought
#Text= on  only  at  dessert  for  the  purpose  of  finishing  up  with,  being  often  drunk  after  port.
#Text=Now,  however,  it  is  a most  common  custom  to  drink  claret  with  dinner  instead  of
#Text= beer.
#Text=Of  course  the  reason  is  that  claret,  and  good  claret  too,  can  be  now  obtained
#Text= in  this  country  at  a very  cheap  rate.
#Text=Indeed,  a most  excellent  sound  claret  can
#Text= be  bought  for  16  s.
#Text=a dozen — only  go  to  a respectable  wine  merchant,  and  always
#Text= taste  the  wine  before  you  buy  it.
#Text=We  will  now  endeavour  to  examine  into  the  general  principles  to  be  observed  in
#Text= the  service  of  wine.
#Text=For  instance,  we  know  that  it  is  customary  to  take  a glass  of
#Text= Chablis  with  oysters,  a glass  of  Madeira  after  turtle  soup,  a glass  of  dry  sherry  with
#Text= fish,  &c.,  but  why  we  do  so  is  by  no  means  so  evident.
#Text=Nature  seems  to  tell  us  that
#Text= port  wine  would  be  unsuitable  with  fish,  nor  do  we  think  any  one  would  care  to  sip
#Text= hock,  however  good,  with  walnuts.
#Text=However,  we  learn  by  experience  that  there  are  certain  flavours  that  combine
#Text= together,  and  apparently  suit,  and  others  that  do  not.
#Text=For  instance,  Chablis  after
#Text= oysters.
#Text=Oysters  have  a strong  flavour,  and  a light  thin  wine  like  Chablis  cleanses
#Text= the  palate  after  eating  them,  and  somehow  the  oyster  seems  to  make  the  wine  taste
#Text= better.
#Text=On  the  other  hand,  try  a glassful  of  champagne  after  eating  oysters,  and  you
#Text= will  find  that  you  cannot  detect  the  flavour  of  the  champagne  at  all.
#Text=Again,  turtle
#Text= is  a rich,  glutinous  soup,  and  after  a very  rich  dish  some  wine  is  required  to  cleanse
#Text= the  palate  of  a more  generous  nature  than.
#Text=Chablis  or  hock : consequently,  Madeira,  or
#Text= good  East  India  sherry,  or  rum  punch,  is  taken.
#Text=After  a light  entree,  such  as  a Vol-au-vent  a la  Financiere,  or  boiled  fish  of  any
#Text= kind,  or  whitebait,  hock  or  pale  sherry  would  be  most  appropriate.
#Text=After  a rich
#Text= and  glutinous  fish  like  stewed  eels,  or  after  any  entree  with  strong  l ' ich  brown  gravy,
#Text= the  palate  requires  something  rather  more  stimulating,  and,  in  my  opinion,  no  wine
#Text= in  the  world  is  equal  to  Burgundy  to  drink  with  dinner,  either  with  water  or  with-
#Text= out.
#Text=Still,  claret,  though  not  so  stimulating,  is  an  admirable  wine  to  drink  after
#Text= rich  dishes.
#Text=I think  it  will  be  found  that  the  general  principle,  that  the  richer  the  dish  the
#Text= more  stimulating  must  be  the  -wine,  holds  true  for  nearly  all  kinds  of  food.
#Text=For
#Text=instance,  roast  pork  is  a rich  dish,  and  it  is  one  of  the  few  kinds  of  food  that  persons
#Text= drink  port  wine  after.
#Text=Roast  goose  is  another  rich  dish,  and  it  is  customary  after
#Text= eating  roast  goose  to  have  a small  liquor  glass  of  brandy.
#Text=I have  a little  further  on  quoted  Francatelli’s  opinion  with  regard  to  the  service
#Text= of  wine,  and  it  will  be  seen  that  he  particularly  calls  attention  to  the  absurd  custom
#Text= of  serving  sweet  champagne  early  in  dinner.
#Text=As  a rule,  however,  champagne  is
#Text= generally  dry  in  this  country.
#Text=The  Duke  de  Montebello’s  sec,  Pommery  and  Greno’s
#Text= extra  sec,  and  Heidseck’s  Monopole,  are  all  admirable  dry  wines,  and  we  think
#Text= the  former,  though  not  equal  in  repute  to  the  two  latter,  is  quite  their  equal,  both
#Text= in  quality  and  flavour.
#Text=I would,  however,  caution  persons  against  introducing  champagne  early  in  the
#Text= dinner  at  all,  whether  it  be  dry  or  not.
#Text=Indeed,  it  will  be  found  best  if  the  cham-
#Text= pagne be  dry  not  to  serve  it  till  the  pRce  de  resistance  has  made  its  appearance.
#Text=If  the  champagne  be  at  all  sweet,  it  had  better  not  be  served  till  the  sweets.
#Text=The  French  taste  is  far  sweeter  than  the  English:  for  instance,  you  will  often
#Text= see  a body  of  grown-up  Frenchmen  enjoying  sweets  and  dessert,  including  even
#Text= sugar  plums,  in  a way  that  in  England  is  only  seen  with  young  children.

#Text= pagne  in  France  is  almost  universally  drank  after  dinner  in  the  same  way  in  which
#Text= we  should  finish  up  with  a bottle  of  claret.
#Text=But  then  it  should  be  remembered  that
#Text= the  majority  of  the  champagne  in  France  is  very  sweet ; the  champagne-growers
#Text= adapting  nearly  the  whole  of  the  wine  that  is  sent  to  England  to  suit  the  English
#Text= taste,  and  it  will  generally  be  found  that  champagne  in  England  has  the  word
#Text= “ England  ” branded  on  the  side  of  the  cork.
#Text=How  far  the  French  are  right  and  we  wrong,  or  vice  versd,  in  thus  preferring
#Text= swreet  champagne  to  dry  is  a matter  of  taste.
#Text=However, . there  can  be  no  doubt  that
#Text= the  taste  for  dry  wines  can  be  carried  too  far,  and  that  there  should  be  some  limit
#Text= beyond  which  the  dryness  of  a wine  should  not  be  carried.
#Text=For  instance,  take  the
#Text= case  of  the  Duke  of  Montebello’s  first  brand  : there  is  the  sec  and  the  maximum
#Text=country  produces.
#Text=There  are  samples  that  correspond  to  Hock,  Sherry,  Burgundy,
#Text= Claret,  and  Madeira.
#Text=We  will  first  take  the  kind  that  resembles  hock.
#Text=This  is  called
#Text= Riesling • it  is  a thin  light  wine,  sold  in  hock  bottles,  and  is  an  exceedingly  pleasant
#Text= drink  in  summer,  and  is  particularly  suitable  with  boiled  fish,  or  after  light  entrees,
#Text= such  as  vol-au-vents.
#Text=Highercombe  is  another  wine  resembling  hock,  or  rather
#Text= Haut  Barsac  or  Sauterne.
#Text=Highercombe  is  a strong-scented  wine,  and  would
#Text= probably  not  be  liked  by  those  who  are  partial  to  an  exceedingly  dry  sherry.
#Text=On  the  other  hand,  when  the  taste  for  this  wine  has  been  acquired,  it  is  generally
#Text= very  strongly  fancied.
#Text=Some  of  this  wine  mixed  with  a bottle  of  soda-water  will  be
#Text= found  a most  refreshing  drink.
#Text=Another  Australian  wine  very  much  resembling
#Text= hock  is  Gouais ; this  wine  is  something  between  hock  and  Sauterne,  and,  as  it  can
#Text= be  bought  for  24s.
#Text=a dozen,  is  well  worth  a trial.
#Text=The  next  class  of  wines  to  which
#Text= we  would  refer  is  the  white  Australian  wines  that  resemble  sherry.
#Text=First  we
#Text= will  take  Fairfield  (amber).
#Text=This  wine  very  much  resembles  Cape  Sherry,  and  is
#Text= certjcinly  inferior  to  ordinary  good  sherry ; it  also  has  a slight  resemblance  to  the
#Text= home-made  wine  one  occasionally  tastes  at  farmhouses  that  is  made  from  rhubarb.
#Text=This  wine  is,  however,  very  wholesome,  and  probably  after  a time  would  be  very
#Text= palatable  when  the  taste  for  it  is  once  acquired.
#Text=A very  superior  wine,  however,  is
#Text= met  with  in  V erdeilho ; this  is  made  from  vines  resembling  those  in  Madeira,  and
#Text=
#Text=even  cheaper,  and,  when  the  specimens  are  good,  is  well  worth  double  the  money.
#Text=We  would  strongly  advise  connoisseurs  and  epicures  to  make  a trial.
#Text=A very
#Text= delicious  cup,  superior  to  Moselle  cup,  can  be  made  from  this  wine,  by  mixing  it
#Text= with  soda-water,  sugar,  a few  slices  of  lemon,  and  a lump  of  ice.
#Text=This  makes  a
#Text= cheap  and  very  refreshing  drink  in  summer.
#Text=We  next  come  to  the  Australian  red  wines,  which,  as  a rule,  will  be  found  very
#Text= superior  to  the  white.
#Text=The  finest  Australian  red  wine  that  I have  ever  tasted  is
#Text= called  Carbenet.
#Text=This  fine  wine  has  a most  beautiful  bouquet,  resembling  good
#Text= Chateau  Margaux  claret.
#Text=It  resembles  Burgundy  in  flavour,  with  perhaps  a
#Text= very  slight  port  flavour  added.
#Text=Or  it  may  be  compared  to  a veiy  dry  Bousillon.
#Text=This  wine  is  very  soft,  and  this,  coupled  with  its  rich-scented  bouquet,  entitles  it
#Text= to  rank  high  among  the  Australian  wines.
#Text=Indeed,  it  is  far  supei’ior  to  the  general
#Text= run  of  Burgundies  and  clarets  that  can  be  bought  at  the  same  price,  which  is  about
#Text= 36s.
#Text=a dozen.
#Text=Fairfield  (ruby)  is  another  red  wine,  somewhat  resembling  dry  port.
#Text=The  bouquet  of  this  wine  is  very  inferior  to  Carbenet,  and  it  has  a rather  dead  taste,
#Text= in  which  can  be  detected  a slight  flavour  of  raisins.
#Text=Perhaps  the  next  best  wine  to
#Text= Carbenet  is  Mataro ; this  is  also  similar  to  a dry  port  or  Burgundy ; it  has  a good
#Text= bouquet,  and  is  well  worth  the  price  at  which  it  is  generally  sold.
#Text=Chaselas  is  a
#Text= red  wine,  but  is  somewhat  poor  and  acid.
#Text=A better  wine  is  Hermitage,  which
#Text=somewhat  resembles  the  Hermitage  made  on  the  banks  of  the  Rhone,  and  is  pro-
#Text= bably named  after  it.
#Text=A very  peculiar  Australian  wine  is  made  called  Conatto ;
#Text= this  is  a rich  liqueur,  with  a slightly  medicinal  flavour  in  it ; its  taste  reminds  one
#Text= of  rum  shrub  and  curatjoa.
#Text=Again,  it  is  sometimes  like  Constantia,  and  is  probably
#Text= made  from  the  same  kind  of  grapes  that  are  used  for  Constantia.
#Text=Red  Albury  is  a
#Text= scented  wine  resembling  somewhat  English  home-made  raisin  wine,  only  it  is  better.
#Text=It  is  a capital  wine  for  children,  and  would  suit  those  who  like  a sweet  port.
#Text=These
#Text= are  the  chief  wines  of  Australia,  which,  in  our  opinion,  are  destined  in  a few  years’
#Text= time  to  become  far  better  known  than  they  are  at  present ; and  Englishmen  on
#Text= patriotic  grounds  should  at  any  rate  give  Australian  wines  a trial,  if  their  order  does
#Text= not  extend  beyond  a single  bottle.
#Text=We  have  now  run  through  the  principal  wines  drunk  in  this  country,  and  have
#Text= taken  exceptional  notice  of  Australian  wine,  which  is  but  little  known,  owing

#Text= British  dominions.
#Text=Hungarian  wine,  Italian  wine,  Swiss  wine,  are  all  worth  a
